Redesigning consumerfinance.gov

Upgrading the site and its content strategy from reactive and patchwork to sustainable and thoughtful

Background

The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) launched its website, consumerfinance.gov, in 2011. At the time, the CFPB had about 50 employees. Over the next couple years, the agency grew to more than 1000 employees, but the design and engineering resources didn’t grow as quickly. Periodic site redesigns were small and served mostly to pay down technical debt and deliver on overdue promises to program offices. The result was a mishmashed tech stack, inconsistent visual style, and IA with little intentionality.

In 2014, the Technology and Innovation team finally added enough capacity to devote a full-time multidisciplinary team to consumerfinance.gov. As the CFPB’s first content strategist, I joined the team, along with four engineers, two visual designers, two UX designers (one also serving as product manager), and a project manager.

The problem

For a website team, the CFPB presented a big stakeholder management problem. The CFPB was the first federal agency in which the prevailing attitude was the way you make something official is to put it online. So anyone responsible for any agency priority needed the website, and the desire to do it all quickly meant they needed it all the time. Because the agency itself was still establishing its own processes, everyone felt freedom and access to make requests.

There were just as many external audiences we couldn’t ignore: regulated companies, consumer advocates, small-scale financial practitioners and coaches, consumers themselves, policymakers, state regulators, civil and criminal lawyers.

The site had not met the needs of this huge number of stakeholders and audiences. It needed to do that while also being ready to adapt to future needs.

The work

The project began with four priorities: well-organized content, an architecture that supports anticipated needs, unified visual design, and measurable onsite events. I devised a corresponding four-part approach to scope the content strategy work:

  1. Create content and metadata according to the new information architecture.
  2. Use the challenges of using the content (for both administrators and users) to inform platform work.
  3. Shape content to align with the new design direction, and work through specific designs as we apply them to real content.
  4. Identify what we’re analyzing content for.

The universe of what we could have focused on was vast; these constraints kept the content work focused.

Foundational research

We began by building up a knowledge base for the team: internal stakeholder interviews; identifying owners for each content type; research into architecture and front-end framework choices; and exploring the existing digital and print visual styles.

I lead a content audit. I recruited coworkers to assist me and coached them through capturing significant information. We noted missing and bad metadata, opportunities to add more, misused styles, out of date attachments and contact information, etc.

User research

I supported the UX team in conducting a series of user research efforts. First, we got external research recommendations from stakeholders to give us a sense of expert audiences. We learned that there was no simple way to use consumerfinance.gov. Sophisticated users had to know the whole site to find information they couldn’t work without. It was easier to email CFPB staffers, even for things that were online.

We conducted further research with non-experts who had recently made significant financial decisions in their own lives. We used various methods over the course of our research and iteration:

  • Affinity diagrams and journey mapping to understand who shapes their financial decisions and how they make those decisions;
  • Card sorts to learn how they think information labels relate to one another and how they would navigate among them;
  • Dot voting to see how they feel about different vocabulary choices for labeling similar information; and
  • Visual preference testing to hear reactions to different voices, tones, design directions, and media elements.

We learned that people took advice from sources they trusted for personal reasons, not for expertise reasons. The .gov in the CFPB’s domain wasn’t worth much; friendly, accessible design went a lot further.

Giving the site structure

The UX team introduced cross-site relationships based on metadata that I assigned to different content. It made related content embeddable, freeing some workflow challenges from sitemap limits while still letting users benefit from a more constrained browsing experience.

The UX team developed a sitemap based on longitudinal user journeys rather than parallel task types. To make this work, navigation menus for each section also needed to be individually tailored. The visual designers created layouts for each, and I worked with them to further group content in ways that created a natural flow for the targeted audiences of each section. We kept the copy short and allowed space for expansion so the sections could work both as we designed it and in the future.

Getting buy-in on section labels proved the trickiest stakeholder management problem: experts had concerns with almost every design choice, but we needed their buy-in because this governed the site as a whole. At the same time, they were pushing us to get something online to show progress for all the time we’d invested. I redirected this pressure in a way that created a stronger relationship with the stakeholders and earned the team more trust to do its work.

I brought the senior management team together, explained the site team’s proposal, and asked them to comment freely. They argued with each other over language for nearly an hour. Eventually some of them suggested the impediment to progress was their lack of agreement, not our work process.

Within a few weeks, we had buy-in to represent navigation on a beta version of the website with language we already had. In turn, we pledged to continue researching and refining, exactly in line with the way we had hoped to work in the first place. The senior managers gave universal praise to beta.consumerfinance.gov when it launched in 2015.

Workflow and governance

Migrating content to the new site required coordinating a number of pieces: drafting, shaping content to the visual design components, circulating for review, and publication. I set up an agreement with the executive secretary to help us circulate content effectively, first on paper and then as designed. I established a process and timeframes for the site team, so every office that worked with us to migrate knew exactly what to expect. I created copy decks based on the IA work, ran initial coaching sessions on the site’s goals and user-centered writing, and then trusted the program offices to write first drafts.

As we began this work with program offices, we brought on an additional content strategist. I served as the team lead and coached her through managing relationships with program offices. We divided responsibility and, as much as possible, co-located with our respective partners while we worked with them to maintain open conversation. Offices owned the accuracy, goals, and priorities, and the site team owned copyediting and the choices for how to represent the content, in line with those initial four goals.

Results

Because of the agency’s caution about how it affected markets, the full launch of the new site didn’t come until 2017. But the style, voice, and architecture we established and iterated on using beta.consumerfinance.gov continue to inform consumerfinance.gov today.

The voice we established for the CFPB lined up with the lighter, friendlier design style. We focused on being informative over being prescriptive. The hierarchy of information was flexible, depending on office priorities, but it consistently fit the new design elements.

We developed metadata tools that supported publication in both the existing and new styles at the same time, making the process as seamless as possible for content managers. Users could benefit from more constrained activity because related content populated into sections that targeted their experience.

We established working relationships with program offices, building up trust that had broken down between content producers and the content management operation that seemed to tell them “no” or “what about over here” as often as “yes.”

All the new page and content types had knowable purposes. When we wanted to measure on-site events, it was easy to know what measures worked best for what content types because we understood what those types were trying to do for users.

consumerfinance.gov continues to evolve. You can follow its progress on the cfgov-refresh GitHub repo.
